_header: Our Host upon his stirrups stood anon
Title(s): ‘Epilogue’ of the Man of Law’s Tale; Canterbury Tales
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the ‘Epilogue’ of the Man of Law’s Tale of the Canterbury Tales — 28 lines in couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
OVre Ost vppon his stiropes stood anoonand seide good men herkeneth
                    euerychoon…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…ne phislyas ne termes queynte of lawether is but litil latyn
                    in my mawe
BodArcSelB14.Note: Functions as a link to the Shipman’s Tale.
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And / next folwith the Shipman his prolog (f. 157); the Shipman
                    (RT); Here endith the Shipman his prolog… (f. 157v)

BodBar20.First Lines:
Owre ost vpon his stiropes stood anonAnd saide godemen herkenyth
                    euerychon…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…Ne philyas ne termes of laweTher is but litul latyn in my
                    mawe
BodBar20.Note: Functions as a link to the Squire’s Tale.
BodBar20.Attributed Title:
…and here bygynnyth þe prolog of þe squyer (f.
                        78v); squyer (RT) Here endith þe prolog of a
                    þe / Squyers tale… (f. 78v)

BodRawPoe141.First Lines:
OVre ost vp on his styrop styrt anonAnd seyde good men herkeneth
                    euerychon…
BodRawPoe141.Last Lines:
…Ne physik ne termes queynte of laweTher is but lytell latyn
                    in my mawe
BodRawPoe141.Note:
II.1187 omitted; spurious line follows 1188; 1173-4 reversed. Functions
                    as a link to the Squire’s Tale.
BodRawPoe141.Attributed Title:
Here bigynneth the squyers tale (f. 47v); The squyer
                    (RT)

BodRawPoe149.First Lines:
Oure hoste vppon his stiroppe stode anoneAnd seide goodemen
                    herkeneth euerychon…
BodRawPoe149.Last Lines:

BLEge2863.First Lines:
Oure oost vpon his styropes stood anoonAnd seide gode men herkeneth
                    euerichon…
BLEge2863.Last Lines:
…He schal no gospell glosen here ne techeHe leueth all in the
                    grete god he…
BLEge2863.Note:
II.1182-90 lost. Functions as a link to the Squire’s
                    Tale.
BLEge2863.Attributed Title:
…And here bygynneth þe prologe of þe Squier (f.
                        61v)

BLHar1758.First Lines:
Our oost vp on his stiropes stood a nonAnd seide good men herkeneth
                    euerychon…
BLHar1758.Last Lines:
…Ne speke no termes queynte of laweThere is but litell latyn
                    in my mawe
BLHar1758.Note: Functions as a link to the Squire’s Tale.
BLHar1758.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth the prolog of the Squyers tale (f. 68); The Squyers Tale
                    (RT); Here endith the Prolog… (f. 68)

BLHar7333.First Lines:
Ovre hoste on his stiropis stode a nonAnd seithe goodemen
                    harkenithe euerychon…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…Ne phisilias ne termes queynte of laweTher is but litill
                    latyne in my mawe
BLHar7333.Note: Functions as a link to the Squire’s Tale.

BLHar7334.First Lines:
Our Ost vppon his styrops stood anoonAnd seyde good men herkneth
                    euerychoon…
BLHar7334.Last Lines:
…And þerfor ost I warne þe byfornMy ioly body schal
                    a tale telle
BLHar7334.Note:
II.1175 left blank; 1186-90 omitted; ‘Sayde the sompnour’ is
                    the reading at 1179 even though the Wife of Bath’s Prologue
                    follows.
BLHar7334.Attributed Title: Here endith the Man of Lawe his tale… (f. 86v)
BLHar7334.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Harleian MS 7334 of Chaucer’s ‘Canterbury
                Tales’.
Chaucer Society
         73. London: Trübner, 1885.

BLLan851.First Lines:
OWre Ost vpon his stereps stode anoneAnd seide goode mon
                    herkeneþ euerychone…
BLLan851.Last Lines:
…Ne fisleas ne
                    turnies
                    queynte of laweThere is bot litel latine in my mawe
BLLan851.Note: Functions as a link to the Squire’s Tale.

Chaucer Society

            1868-79.

BLRoy17Dxv.First Lines:
Ower Oste vpoon his styropes stode anoneAnd sayde gode Men
                    harkeneþe euerychone…
BLRoy17Dxv.Last Lines:
…Ne fyslias ne termes qweynte of laweTher nys butte litulle
                    latyne in my mawe
BLRoy17Dxv.Note:
II.1187 omitted with spurious line following 1188; the
                    ‘Merchant’s Endlink’ (745) and ‘Squire’s Headlink’
                        (5024) follow
                    with the whole sequence functioning as a link to the Squire’s
                    Tale.
BLRoy17Dxv.Attributed Title:
…And begynnythe the prologe of the Squyre (f.
                    95v)
